item.title: Mountain Ways
item.dc:creator: Ursula K. Le Guin
item.description: In the stony uplands of the Deka Mountains the farmholds are few and far between.

item.title: Nine Lives
item.dc:creator: Ursula K. Le Guin
item.description: She was alive inside but dead outside, her face a black and dun net of wrinkles, tumors, cracks. She was bald and blind.

item.title: The New Atlantis
item.dc:creator: Ursula K. Le Guin
item.description: Coming back from my Wilderness Week, I sat by an odd sort of man in the bus. For a long time we didn’t talk; I was mending stockings and he was reading.

item.title: Extreme Solitude
item.dc:creator: Ursula K. Le Guin
item.description: MR. UNDERHILL CAME out from under his hill, smiling and breathing hard. Each breath shot out of his nostrils as a double puff of steam, snow-white in the morning sunshine.

item.title: The Stars Below
item.dc:creator: Ursula K. Le Guin
item.description: The wooden house and outbuildings caught fire fast, blazed up, burned down, but the dome, built of lathe and plaster above a drum of brick, would not burn.

item.title: The Obscure Object
item.dc:creator: Ursula K. Le Guin
item.description: Short story about the narrator’s crush on her friend, the Object. The narrator, Calliope, realizes, throughout the course of the story, that

item.title: The Fountains
item.dc:creator: Ursula K. Le Guin
item.description: They knew, having given him cause, that Dr. Kereth might attempt to seek political asylum in Paris.

item.title: The Island of the Immortals
item.dc:creator: Ursula K. Le Guin
item.description: Somebody asked me if I’d heard that there were immortal people on the Yendian Plane, and somebody else told me that there were, so when I got there, I asked about them.

item.title: Seasons of Ansarac
item.dc:creator: Ursula K. Le Guin
item.description: I talked for a long time once with an old Ansar. I met him at his Interplanary Hostel, which is on a large island far out in the Great Western Ocean

item.title: Elementals
item.dc:creator: Ursula K. Le Guin
item.description: No one knows how many airlings there are, most likely not a great many, whatever a great many means.

item.title: The Silence of the Asonu
item.dc:creator: Ursula K. Le Guin
item.description: The silence of the Asonu is proverbial. The first visitors believed that these gracious, gracile people were mute, lacking any language other than that of gesture, expression, and gaze.

item.title: Findings
item.dc:creator: Ursula K. Le Guin
item.description: She wrote a story in the past tense. Her story told how she waited in the garden while he crossed the deserts and sailed the seas and won great victories

item.title: Findings
item.dc:creator: Ursula K. Le Guin
item.description: Thin bluish clouds move northeastwards high up and slowly. Help this soul, southwest wind of the rainy season, help this soul be healed

item.title: For Judith
item.dc:creator: Ursula K. Le Guin
item.description: But it’s a soft word, Judith! If you said a word for its softness, you might say billowy, or valley floor, or lesbian.

item.title: The Elders at the Falls
item.dc:creator: Ursula K. Le Guin
item.description: I heard this story. They stood all day with their backs turned.

item.title: The Skin
item.dc:creator: Ursula K. Le Guin
item.description: “All around us is the skin, helping keep our bodies in.”
